questions.text: What is the primary difference between incidence and prevalence?

options.label: A
options.text: Incidence refers to the total number of cases, while prevalence refers to the proportion of the population affected.

options.label: B
options.text: Incidence refers to the proportion of the population affected, while prevalence refers to the total number of cases.

options.label: C
options.text: Incidence measures new cases, while prevalence measures existing cases.

options.label: D
options.text: Incidence measures existing cases, while prevalence measures new cases.

questions.correct_answer: C. Incidence measures new cases, while prevalence measures existing cases.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of calculating HALE?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the economic productivity of a country

options.label: B
options.text: To assess the burden of disease by combining years of life lost due to premature mortality and years lived with disability

options.label: C
options.text: To evaluate the quality of life of individuals with disabilities

options.label: D
options.text: To estimate the number of years an individual can expect to live in good health

questions.correct_answer: D. To estimate the number of years an individual can expect to live in good health

questions.text: Which of the following is a target of SDG Goal 3 related to child health?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduce the Infant Mortality rate to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030

options.label: B
options.text: Reduce the under-5 mortality rate to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030

options.label: C
options.text: Reduce the Neonatal mortality rate to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030

options.label: D
options.text: Reduce the stillbirth rate to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030

questions.correct_answer: B. Reduce the under-5 mortality rate to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030

questions.text: Vaccines under NIS doesn’t protect children against:

options.label: A
options.text: Tuberculosis

options.label: B
options.text: Measles

options.label: C
options.text: Tetanus

options.label: D
options.text: Cholera

questions.correct_answer: D. Cholera

questions.text: What is the most effective method for preventing transmission of HIV from mother to child during childbirth?

options.label: A
options.text: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) during pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Cesarean section delivery

options.label: C
options.text: Formula feeding instead of breastfeeding

options.label: D
options.text: Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)

questions.correct_answer: A. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) during pregnancy

questions.text: The most common vector responsible for the transmission of disease which is usually detected by rK39 rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) in India is:

options.label: A
options.text: Aedes mosquito

options.label: B
options.text: Anopheles mosquito

options.label: C
options.text: Culex mosquito

options.label: D
options.text: Sandfly

questions.correct_answer: D. Sandfly

questions.text: Stage 1 and stage 4 of demographic transition model describes the transition from:

options.label: A
options.text: High birth rates and high death rates to low birth rates and low death rates

options.label: B
options.text: Low birth rates and low death rates to high birth rates and high death rates

options.label: C
options.text: High birth rates and low death rates to low birth rates and high death rates

options.label: D
options.text: Low birth rates and high death rates to high birth rates and low death rates

questions.correct_answer: A. High birth rates and high death rates to low birth rates and low death rates

questions.text: Which of the following measures of central tendency is most affected by outliers?

options.label: A
options.text: Mean

options.label: B
options.text: Median

options.label: C
options.text: Mode

options.label: D
options.text: Range

questions.correct_answer: A. Mean

questions.text: In a study investigating the association between smoking and lung cancer, what type of study design is most appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Case-control study

options.label: B
options.text: Cohort study

options.label: C
options.text: Cross-sectional study

options.label: D
options.text: Randomized controlled trial

questions.correct_answer: B. Cohort study

questions.text: A study is conducted to investigate the association between alcohol consumption and liver disease. The study finds a relative risk of 2.5. What does this indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Individuals who consume alcohol have a 2.5 times higher risk of liver disease compared to non-drinkers.

options.label: B
options.text: Alcohol consumption decreases risk of liver disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Liver disease leads to increased alcohol consumption.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no association between alcohol consumption and liver disease.

questions.correct_answer: A. Individuals who consume alcohol have a 2.5 times higher risk of liver disease compared to non-drinkers.

questions.text: What is the purpose of blinding in a randomized controlled trial?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent selection bias

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent measurement bias

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent confounding bias

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent observer bias

questions.correct_answer: D. To prevent observer bias

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of calculating the confidence interval (CI) in epidemiological studies?

options.label: A
options.text: To estimate the precision of the sample mean

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the statistical significance of the study findings

options.label: C
options.text: To assess the potential for bias in the study

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a range of values within which the true population parameter is likely to lie

questions.correct_answer: D. To provide a range of values within which the true population parameter is likely to lie

questions.text: Which of the following is not a measure of central tendency?

options.label: A
options.text: Mean

options.label: B
options.text: Mode

options.label: C
options.text: Median

options.label: D
options.text: Range

questions.correct_answer: D. Range

questions.text: Which of the following is not a vector-borne disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Malaria

options.label: B
options.text: Tuberculosis

options.label: C
options.text: Dengue Fever

options.label: D
options.text: Japanese Encephalitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Tuberculosis

questions.text: The term "incubation period" refers to:

options.label: A
options.text: The period during which a person is infectious to others.

options.label: B
options.text: The period from exposure to onset of symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: The period from onset of symptoms to recovery.

options.label: D
options.text: The period during which a disease outbreak occurs.

questions.correct_answer: B. The period from exposure to onset of symptoms.

questions.text: The "epidemiological triad" of disease consists of:

options.label: A
options.text: Agent, host, and environment.

options.label: B
options.text: Pathogen, vector, and reservoir.

options.label: C
options.text: Exposure, susceptibility, and outcome.

options.label: D
options.text: Cause, effect, and prevention.

questions.correct_answer: A. Agent, host, and environment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the case fatality rate (CFR)?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the total number of deaths in a population.

options.label: B
options.text: It measures the severity of a disease outbreak.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the ratio of deaths from a specific disease to the total number of cases of that disease.

options.label: D
options.text: It indicates the rate at which a disease spreads within a community.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the ratio of deaths from a specific disease to the total number of cases of that disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a zoonotic disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Measles

options.label: B
options.text: Rabies

options.label: C
options.text: Typhoid Fever

options.label: D
options.text: Mumps

questions.correct_answer: B. Rabies

questions.text: The term "endemic" refers to:

options.label: A
options.text: A disease that occurs at a consistent rate within a specific geographic area.

options.label: B
options.text: A sudden increase in the number of cases of a disease within a population.

options.label: C
options.text: A disease that occurs sporadically across different regions.

options.label: D
options.text: The complete eradication of a disease from a population.

questions.correct_answer: A. A disease that occurs at a consistent rate within a specific geographic area.

questions.text: Eligible couple register is maintained by?

options.label: A
options.text: ASHA Worker at subcenter

options.label: B
options.text: ANM at subcenter

options.label: C
options.text: MPHW (M) at subcenter

options.label: D
options.text: Anganwadi Worker at Anganwadi center

questions.correct_answer: B. ANM at subcenter

questions.text: Which of the following is not a barrier method?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaginal sponge

options.label: B
options.text: Female condom

options.label: C
options.text: Spermicidal jellies

options.label: D
options.text: IUCD

questions.correct_answer: D. IUCD

questions.text: Which healthcare principle is described by the "rule of halves"?

options.label: A
options.text: The rule that suggests dividing a patient's medication dosage in half to minimize side effects.

options.label: B
options.text: A guideline stating that half of the population will experience a certain health condition at some point in their lives.

options.label: C
options.text: A concept indicating that only half of the prescribed treatment or interventions for a condition are typically completed or adhered to by patients.

options.label: D
options.text: A principle suggesting that about half of the people with a particular health issue are aware of their condition, half of those who are aware seek medical care, and half of those who seek care receive adequate treatment.

questions.correct_answer: D. A principle suggesting that about half of the people with a particular health issue are aware of their condition, half of those who are aware seek medical care, and half of those who seek care receive adequate treatment.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes the significance of the "90-70-90" pattern in cervical cancer screening?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the recommended ages for cervical cancer screening - 90% of women should begin screening at age 70 and continue every 90 months thereafter.

options.label: B
options.text: It refers to the distribution of cervical cancer cases globally, with 90% occurring in women aged 70 and older, with a 90% survival rate.

options.label: C
options.text: It indicates the proportion of cervical cancer cases caused by HPV strains covered by current vaccines, with 90% coverage in women aged 70 and older.

options.label: D
options.text: It signifies the ideal performance of cervical cancer screening programs, aiming for 90% of eligible women to be screened, with 70% screened regularly and 90% of abnormal results followed up appropriately.

questions.correct_answer: D. It signifies the ideal performance of cervical cancer screening programs, aiming for 90% of eligible women to be screened, with 70% screened regularly and 90% of abnormal results followed up appropriately.

questions.text: Which statement best describes the WHO STEPS approach in public health?

options.label: A
options.text: It outlines strategies for maintaining mental health through stress management techniques recommended by the World Health Organization.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a framework developed by the World Health Organization for monitoring and assessing noncommunicable disease risk factors.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides guidelines for implementing hygiene protocols and infection control measures in healthcare settings, as recommended by the World Health Organization.

options.label: D
options.text: It focuses on promoting physical activity and exercise routines endorsed by the World Health Organization for combating obesity and sedentary lifestyles.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a framework developed by the World Health Organization for monitoring and assessing noncommunicable disease risk factors.

questions.text: What does the term "demographic window" typically refer to in the context of population dynamics?

options.label: A
options.text: A physical barrier that separates different demographic groups within a population.

options.label: B
options.text: A period in a country's demographic transition where the proportion of working-age population is relatively high.

options.label: C
options.text: The statistical analysis of demographic data collected from various sources.

options.label: D
options.text: A government policy aimed at regulating population growth through incentives and disincentives.

questions.correct_answer: B. A period in a country's demographic transition where the proportion of working-age population is relatively high.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes Antara contraceptive?

options.label: A
options.text: Antara is a male contraceptive pill designed to inhibit sperm production.

options.label: B
options.text: Antara is a brand of emergency contraceptive pill effective up to 72 hours after unprotected intercourse.

options.label: C
options.text: Antara is an intrauterine device (IUD) implanted in women to prevent pregnancy.

options.label: D
options.text: Antara is a progestin-only contraceptive injection administered every 12 weeks to prevent ovulation.

questions.correct_answer: D. Antara is a progestin-only contraceptive injection administered every 12 weeks to prevent ovulation.

questions.text: What does the National Family Planning Indemnity Scheme primarily aim to provide?

options.label: A
options.text: Financial support for families planning to adopt children domestically.

options.label: B
options.text: Legal protection for individuals seeking family planning services.

options.label: C
options.text: Compensation for adverse effects resulting from family planning methods.

options.label: D
options.text: Educational resources for promoting family planning awareness nationwide.

questions.correct_answer: C. Compensation for adverse effects resulting from family planning methods.

questions.text: What condition is most likely affecting a 6-year-old child presenting with poor growth, frequent infections, delayed wound healing, thin and brittle hair, and signs of dermatitis around the mouth?

options.label: A
options.text: Iron deficiency anaemia

options.label: B
options.text: Vitamin D deficiency

options.label: C
options.text: Zinc deficiency

options.label: D
options.text: Protein-energy malnutrition

questions.correct_answer: C. Zinc deficiency

questions.text: According to Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) guidelines, what does the term "RDA" represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The maximum amount of a nutrient that can be safely consumed daily without risk of adverse effects.

options.label: B
options.text: The average daily dietary intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a specific life stage and gender group.

options.label: C
options.text: The minimum amount of a nutrient required to prevent severe deficiency symptoms in the general population.

options.label: D
options.text: The recommended amount of a nutrient to be consumed daily, regardless of individual differences or health conditions.

questions.correct_answer: B. The average daily dietary intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a specific life stage and gender group.

questions.text: What does JSY (Janani Suraksha Yojana) primarily aim to achieve?

options.label: A
options.text: Providing financial assistance for the construction of household toilets in rural areas.

options.label: B
options.text: Promoting awareness about the importance of maternal and child health through community education programs.

options.label: C
options.text: Offering financial incentives to pregnant women for delivering babies in healthcare facilities.

options.label: D
options.text: Ensuring access to free healthcare services for pregnant women and newborns in urban slums.

questions.correct_answer: C. Offering financial incentives to pregnant women for delivering babies in healthcare facilities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, joint pain, and fatigue. Upon examination, a blue-black line is noted along the gingival margin, known as the Burtonian line. The patient works in a paint factory. What condition is most likely present in this patient, given the clinical findings and occupational history?

options.label: A
options.text: Mercury poisoning

options.label: B
options.text: Arsenic poisoning

options.label: C
options.text: Lead poisoning

options.label: D
options.text: Cadmium poisoning

questions.correct_answer: C. Lead poisoning

questions.text: How is sensitivity calculated?

options.label: A
options.text: Sensitivity = True Positive / (True Positive + False Positive)

options.label: B
options.text: Sensitivity = True Positive / (True Positive + False Negative)

options.label: C
options.text: Sensitivity = True Negative / (True Negative + False Positive)

options.label: D
options.text: Sensitivity = True Negative / (True Negative + False Negative)

questions.correct_answer: B. Sensitivity = True Positive / (True Positive + False Negative)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of mean?

options.label: A
options.text: Arithmetic mean

options.label: B
options.text: Geometric mean

options.label: C
options.text: Harmonic mean

options.label: D
options.text: Variance mean

questions.correct_answer: D. Variance mean

questions.text: Consider a dataset representing the heights of students in a class. The heights follow a normal distribution with a mean of 160 cm and a standard deviation of 10 cm. If a randomly selected student from this class has a height of 170 cm, what is the z-score for this student's height?
Which of the following best defines the Total Fertility Rate (TFR)?

options.label: A
options.text: The average number of children a woman gives birth to during her lifetime.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of live births per 1,000 women in a given population.

options.label: C
options.text: The percentage of women of childbearing age who are currently pregnant.

options.label: D
options.text: The ratio of children under the age of 5 to the total population.

questions.correct_answer: A. The average number of children a woman gives birth to during her lifetime.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the Shakir tape in public health assessments?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: To assess body mass index (BMI)

options.label: C
options.text: To estimate mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC)

options.label: D
options.text: To screen for vision problems

questions.correct_answer: C. To estimate mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC)

questions.text: Which of the following populations is considered a priority group for tuberculosis screening and treatment under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme?

options.label: A
options.text: Individuals above 60 years of age

options.label: B
options.text: Healthcare workers

options.label: C
options.text: Pregnant women

options.label: D
options.text: Individuals living with HIV/AIDS

questions.correct_answer: D. Individuals living with HIV/AIDS

questions.text: Which of the following consequences is most likely when a researcher erroneously accepts a false null hypothesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I error

options.label: B
options.text: Type II error

options.label: C
options.text: Power of the study increases

options.label: D
options.text: Confidence interval widens

questions.correct_answer: B. Type II error

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of phases in the disaster cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: Preparedness, Response, Mitigation

options.label: B
options.text: Response, Preparedness, Mitigation

options.label: C
options.text: Response, Recovery, Rehabilitation

options.label: D
options.text: Recovery, Response, Preparedness, Mitigation

questions.correct_answer: C. Response, Recovery, Rehabilitation

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a case-control study?

options.label: A
options.text: A study design that follows a group of individuals over time to observe the development of a disease.

options.label: B
options.text: A study design that compares individuals with a particular condition or disease (cases) to those without the condition (controls) to identify potential risk factors.

options.label: C
options.text: A study design that randomly assigns participants to different treatment groups to assess the effectiveness of an intervention.

options.label: D
options.text: A study design that collects information about a population at a single point in time to estimate prevalence rates of a disease.

questions.correct_answer: B. A study design that compares individuals with a particular condition or disease (cases) to those without the condition (controls) to identify potential risk factors.
